questions.text: Which of the following best describes Tangier disease?

A 12-year-old boy presents with developmental delays, visual impairment, and recurrent episodes of ataxia. Laboratory tests reveal low serum levels of triglycerides, cholesterol, and fat-soluble vitamins. A blood smear shows the presence of acanthocytes. Which of the following findings is most likely present in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Elevated levels of chylomicrons in the bloodstream.

options.label: D
options.text: High serum levels of low-density lipoprotein (LDL).

questions.correct_answer: B. Absence of apolipoprotein B-containing lipoproteins.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the mechanisms of lipoprotein lipase (LPL) activity in post-heparinized blood samples. They conduct a mixing study to differentiate between a deficiency of apolipoprotein C-II (Apo C-II) and LPL deficiency. Which of the following outcomes from the mixing study would most accurately indicate an Apo C-II deficiency?

options.label: A
options.text: The addition of pooled normal plasma results in no change in LPL activity.

options.label: B
options.text: LPL activity normalizes after mixing with normal plasma.

options.label: C
options.text: A significant increase in triglyceride levels is observed after mixing.

options.label: D
options.text: LPL activity decreases following the addition of normal plasma.

questions.correct_answer: B. LPL activity normalizes after mixing with normal plasma.

questions.text: Match the following contributing factors with their corresponding effects on fatty liver: A) Choline Deficiency 1) Increases NADH, hindering fatty acid oxidation and promoting triacylglycerol accumulation. B) Orotic Acid Interference 2) Impairs VLDL secretion, resulting in triacylglycerol accumulation and a fatty liver. C) Vitamin E and Selenium 3) Involved in pyrimidine synthesis. Disrupts VLDL glycosylation, hindering release. D) Ethanol Consumption 4) Protect against liver damage from lipid peroxidation
questions.explanation:
Fatty Liver-Contributing Factors

Choline Deficiency
  • Choline is crucial for lipid metabolism.
  • Deficiency impairs VLDL secretion, resulting in triacylglycerol accumulation and a fatty liver.

Orotic Acid Interference
  • Involved in pyrimidine synthesis
  • Disrupts VLDL glycosylation, hindering release.

Nutritional Deficiencies
  • Deficiencies in essential fatty acids, vitamins (linoleic acid, pyridoxine, pantothenic acid), and protein contribute to fatty liver.

Ethanol Consumption
  • Ethanol metabolism increases NADH, hindering fatty acid oxidation and promoting triacylglycerol accumulation.

Vitamin E and Selenium
  • Protect against liver damage from lipid peroxidation, especially in choline deficiency-induced fatty liver.

questions.text: Which among the following is a true statement on electrophoretic mobility of lipoproteins seen during serum electrophoresis?

options.label: A
options.text: HDL shows the least mobility due to high lipid content.

options.label: B
options.text: Lipoproteins with higher protein content move slower towards the anode.

options.label: C
options.text: Lipoproteins with higher protein content migrate faster towards the anode

options.label: D
options.text: Lipoproteins identified by dye color after staining with lipid dyes, not electrophoretic mobility.

questions.correct_answer: C. Lipoproteins with higher protein content migrate faster towards the anode

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with symptoms of peripheral neuropathy, enlarged tonsils, and orange-colored tonsils. His lipid profile shows very low levels of high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol. Further investigation reveals that the patient has a rare genetic condition leading to severe HDL deficiency. Given these findings, which of the following gene mutations is most likely responsible for this condition?

A 45-year-old woman presents with a history of palmar xanthoma. She reports a family history of similar symptoms. Laboratory tests reveal elevated cholesterol and triglyceride levels, with a cloudy appearance of her plasma.What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.explanation:
TYPE III (Familial Dysbetalipoproteinemia)

Lipoprotein Fraction Elevated

Broad β-VLDL, Chylomicrons

Cholesterol Level

Increased

Triglyceride Level

Increased

Appearance of Plasma

Cloudy

Metabolic Defect
  • Abnormal Apo E
  • Apo CII increased

Features
  • Palmar xanthomas
  • Increased incidence of vascular disease

Management
  • Weight reduction
  • Restrict intake of fat and cholesterol
  • Administer polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFA) and drugs

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately distinguishes Type IIa from Type IIb Hyperlipoproteinemias?

options.label: A
options.text: Plasma after 24 hrs- Type IIa: clear; Type IIb: slightly cloudy.

options.label: B
options.text: Clinical Features- Type IIa: eruptive xanthoma ; Type IIb: corneal arcus.

options.label: C
options.text: Type IIa: VLDL overproduction; Type IIb: LDL and VLDL overproduction.

options.label: D
options.text: Management - Type IIa: restrict fat, supplement MCT; Type IIb: weight reduction, drug therapy.

questions.correct_answer: A. Plasma after 24 hrs- Type IIa: clear; Type IIb: slightly cloudy.
questions.explanation:
Feature

Type IIa (Familial Hypercholesterolemia)

Type IIb (Combined Hyperlipidemia)

Defect

Defective LDL receptors or Apo B-100 ligand region mutation

Increased Apo B, Apo C-II

Lipoprotein Fraction Elevated (Option C)

LDL

LDL and VLDL

Main Lipid Abnormality

Hypercholesterolemia

Combined hyperlipidemia (elevated cholesterol and triglycerides)

Plasma after 24 hours (Option A ruled out)

Clear

Cloudy

Features (Option B ruled out)
  • Atherosclerosis
  • Coronary artery disease (early onset)
  • Tendon xanthomas
  • Corneal arcus.

Management

(Option D ruled out)
  • Statins
  • PUFA
  • Lifestyle modifications (diet, exercise)
  • Statins
  • PUFA
  • Lifestyle modifications (diet, exercise)

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with recurrent episodes of severe abdominal pain and hepatomegaly. Physical examination reveals eruptive xanthomas on his trunk and limbs. Blood tests show a creamy layer over clear plasma after overnight refrigeration. What metabolic defect is most likely present in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Hyperlipoproteinemia

Metabolic defect

Lipid profile

(Increase in: )

Inheritance

Type I

Lipoprotein lipase deficiency

Defect in Apo-C2

Chylomicrons, TG, cholesterol

Autosomal Recessive

Type II A

LDL receptor defect;

Apo B-100 mutation (Option A and B)

Cholesterol

Autosomal Dominant

Type II B

Increased Apo B and Apo CII

Cholesterol, LDL, TG

Autosomal Dominant

Type III

Abnormal Apo E; increased Apo CII(Option D)

Chylomicrons, VLDL

Autosomal Recessive

Type IV

Overproduction of VLDL; increased Apo CII

VLDL, TG

Autosomal Dominant

Type V

Secondary to other conditions

VLDL, TG

Autosomal Dominant

questions.text: Match the apolipoproteins with their respective functions in lipid metabolism: Apolipoprotein Function 1) Apolipoprotein A-I a. Enhances lipoprotein lipase activity, facilitating triglyceride hydrolysis. 2) Apolipoprotein B-100 b. Involved in the transport of dietary lipids from the intestine to other tissues. 3) Apolipoprotein C-II c. Helps in reverse cholesterol transport, removing excess cholesterol from tissue back to liver. 4) Apolipoprotein E d. Essential for binding to LDL receptors on various tissues.
questions.explanation:
Apolipoprotein

Associated Lipoproteins

Function

Apolipoprotein A-I

HDL (High-Density Lipoprotein)

Major protein component of HDL facilitates reverse cholesterol transport, removing excess cholesterol from tissues and transporting it back to the liver.

Apolipoprotein B-100

LDL (Low-Density Lipoprotein)

Main apolipoprotein of LDL; essential for binding to LDL receptors on various tissues, facilitating cholesterol uptake.

Apolipoprotein B-48

Chylomicrons

Main apolipoprotein of chylomicrons; involved in the transport of dietary lipids from the intestine to other tissues.

Apolipoprotein C-II

Chylomicrons, VLDL (Very-Low-Density Lipoprotein)

Acts as a cofactor for lipoprotein lipase, enhancing triglyceride hydrolysis and aiding in lipoprotein metabolism.

Apolipoprotein C-III

VLDL, HDL

Inhibits lipoprotein lipase activity, affecting triglyceride metabolism and lipoprotein clearance.

Apolipoprotein E

Chylomicrons, VLDL, HDL

Facilitates the uptake of triglyceride-rich lipoproteins by cells through interactions with specific receptors; involved in lipid transport and metabolism.

questions.text: Following are the substrates of cholesterol synthesis. Arrange them in order of appearance in the cholesterol synthesis pathway. Mevalonate Squalene Lanosterol Zymosterol Desmosterol

A 45-year-old male presents with a history of progressive kidney dysfunction and recurrent episodes of hemolytic anemia. On examination, the patient is found to have corneal opacification on slit-lamp examination. His lipid profile shows high levels of cholesterol and lipoprotein X. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Partial LCAT Deficiency

(Fish eye disease)

Complete LCAT Deficiency (Norum’s disease)

LCAT Enzyme Activity

Partial loss, mainly affecting corneal lipid metabolism

Severe impairment or absence, leading to systemic issues

Corneal Appearance

Fish-eye appearance due to cholesterol ester accumulation

Fisheye disease: similar corneal opacification

Systemic Involvement

Less severe, primarily ocular

Severe: hemolytic anemia, CKD, early myocardial infarction, progressive End-stage renal disease

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the primary function of Very Low-Density Lipoprotein (VLDL) in the body?

options.label: A
options.text: Transport of dietary cholesterol to the liver

options.label: B
options.text: Transport of triglycerides from the liver to peripheral tissues

options.label: C
options.text: Removal of cholesterol from peripheral tissues to the liver

options.label: D
options.text: Storage of excess cholesterol in adipose tissue

questions.correct_answer: B. Transport of triglycerides from the liver to peripheral tissues

questions.text: The lipid profile of 55 Y/O female is given below: Triglycerides 150 mg/dL Total cholesterol 350 mg/dL HDL 90 mg/dL Calculate LDL level of this patient.
Which enzyme facilitates the conversion of discoidal HDL into spheroidal HDL in HDL metabolism?
What is Apo B48 primarily associated with?
questions.explanation:
Lipoprotein Type

Major Apolipoproteins associated

Chylomicrons

Apo B48, ApoA-I, ApoA-II, ApoC-II, ApoE

VLDL

ApoB-100, ApoC-II, ApoE

LDL

ApoB-100

HDL

ApoA-I, ApoA-II, ApoC-II, ApoE

questions.text: Match the lipoprotein with its function. Lipoprotein Function 1.Chylomicron a.Transports triglycerides from the liver to muscle and adipose tissue 2.Very low-density lipoprotein (VLDL) b.Transports cholesterol from peripheral tissue to the liver 3. Low-density lipoprotein (LDL) c.Transports cholesterol from the liver to peripheral tissues 4. High-density lipoprotein (HDL) d.Transports triglycerides from the gut to muscle and adipose tissue
questions.explanation:
Lipoprotein

Function

Chylomicron

Transports triglycerides from the gut to liver, muscle and adipose tissue

Very low-density lipoprotein (VLDL)

Transports triglycerides from the liver to muscle and adipose tissue

Intermediate-density lipoprotein (IDL)

VLDL remnant

Low-density lipoprotein (LDL)

Transports cholesterol from the liver to peripheral tissues

High-density lipoprotein (HDL)

Transports cholesterol from peripheral tissue to the liver

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding bile acid synthesis regulation? 7α-hydroxylation is the step which is suppressed Cholic acid suppresses the synthesis Farnesoid X receptor is activated Transcription of the CYP7A1 gene is suppressed

Which of the following statements is true regarding the fate of cholesterol? Chenodeoxycholic acid and cholic acid are the primary bile acids Glycine-taurine conjugation happens in liver peroxisomes Intestinal bacteria produce secondary bile acids
Which of the following enzymes catalyzes the principal regulatory step of cholesterol synthesis?
questions.explanation:
Category

Regulation Method

Mechanism

Allosteric Modification

Statins (e.g., Lovastatin)

Competitive inhibition of HMG CoA reductase

Covalent Modification

AMP-activated Kinase

Phosphorylates HMG CoA reductase, inactivating it

Protein Phosphatase 1

Dephosphorylates HMG CoA reductase, activating it

Induction or Repression

Sufficient Cholesterol

Suppresses transcription of the HMG CoA reductase gene

Low Dietary Cholesterol

Increases transcription of the HMG CoA reductase gene

Insulin and Thyroxine

Increase the activity of HMG CoA reductase (induction)

Cortisol and Glucagon

Decrease the activity of HMG CoA reductase (repression)
